THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $30,000,000 equivalent in yuan, comprising (i) an A loan of up to $15,000,000 equivalent in 
yuan and (ii) a complementary loan1 of up to $15,000,000 equivalent in yuan to Chongqing 
Tianzow Animal Husbandry Technology Limited (the borrower) for the Tianzow Advanced Pig 
Breeding Stock Project in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 
2.  The project comprises the construction and operation of a modern pig breeding stock farm 
in Chongqing municipality in the PRC. 2 The Asian Development Bank (ADB) loan will be used for 
(i) the repayment of shareholder loans to the borrower by Sichuan Tianzow Breeding Technology 
Co., Ltd. (Tianzow) to fund the construction of the farm, (ii) biological assets for the farm, and 
(iii) working capital for the first year of farm operations. Through this project, ADB will support the 
supply  of  high-quality  pig  breeding  stock  and  promote  environmentally  sustainable,  high-
efficiency, and high-biosecurity pig production in the PRC. 
 
  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
1.  Project Identification 
 
3.  Livestock in the People’s Republic of China. Livestock contributes to nearly half of total 
gross domestic product generated by agriculture in the PRC. Pork is the most important source 
of animal protein for PRC consumers. However, the PRC pig sector faces the following severe 
issues: biosecurity risks, lack of access to productive pig genetics, large proportion of small pig 
farms with low efficiency and production standards, and environmental concerns. 
 
4.  Biosecurity risks. African swine fever (ASF) has been a big threat to the PRC pig sector. 
The first reported ASF case in the PRC occurred in August 2018, after which the virus spread 
across the country. ASF had reduced the pig population by almost half in the PRC by the end of 
2019, indicating a need to rebuild the herd with strong genetics. A new strain of ASF was found 
in the PRC in late 2020, which affects sows’ reproductive systems. To tackle this pressing 
challenge, the PRC government (i) promoted the recovery of pig farming by expanding large-
scale farms, (ii) intensified efforts to develop a vaccine, (iii) restricted cross-zone transport of live 
pigs, and (iv) increased pork import to meet domestic demand. 
 
5.  Lack of access to productive pig genetics. The average piglets per sow per year (PSY) 
in the PRC pig sector estimated by industry experts was about 20–21 before the ASF outbreak 
and about 15–16 after the ASF outbreak because many farms used commercial pigs as sows3 to 
produce commercial pigs to take advantage of high prices in 2020, which significantly reduced 
production efficiency. The PSY in countries with an advanced pig sector (e.g., in North America 
and Western Europe) can typically reach 24–30. This significant difference in productivity is 
primarily because pig species in countries with an advanced pig sector have more favorable 
 
1  The complementary loan is an ADB syndicated loan product that can be offered in various currencies (including local 
currencies) funded by commercial banks, where ADB is the lender of record. For this project, ADB is seeking approval 
for the A and complementary loan facilities to be denominated in yuan. 
2  The farm will engage in selective breeding, an advanced scientific approach to pair a boar and a gilt or sow to 
incorporate or maintain desired traits. Genetics play an important role in a pig’s productivity and meat quality. There 
are several generations of pig breeding stock such as great grandparent (GGP), grandparent (GP), and F1 (parent). 
3  A female commercial pig is not classified as breeder but is sold for meat.

2  
genetic traits. The PRC government implemented policies to promote the development of the 
domestic pig breeding and subsidize the adoption of productive pig genetics by small-scale farms.  
 
6.  Small pig farms with low efficiency and low standards. Small pig farms with fewer 
than 500 pigs contribute to nearly 50% of annual pig production in the PRC. They tend to overreact 
to market prices, which is a major reason behind the pig price cycle.4 Small pig farms are less 
efficient with low productivity and less advanced animal waste treatment. Small pig farms with 
inadequate biosecurity management systems are expected to bear most of the economic losses 
created by ASF and other diseases. The government has steadily industrialized the sector and is 
aiming for at least 65% of pork from industrial farming operations by 2025. Smaller operations are 
encouraged to use their farms to raise pigs for larger companies (contract farming model). Larger 
pig companies are more likely to make an investment in pig genetics. Pig farming modernization, 
with larger-scale farmers and better genetics, could help to stabilize pig prices. 
 
7.  Environmental concerns. The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations 
reports that livestock contribute to 14.5% of all human-induced greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, 
of which about 81% is attributable to ruminants and 9% to pigs (largely because the GHG 
emission per unit of pork is much lower than that of beef).5 In addition, genetic improvement of 
livestock population is a cost-effective strategy to mitigate climate change and improve the 
adaptive ability of livestock animals to new environments.6 Another major environmental concern 
is pollution from animal waste. The PRC pig sector generates about 864 million tons of animal 
waste per year, equivalent to one-third of total animal waste generated by the PRC livestock 
sector.7 The government has significantly tightened environmental regulations since 2010 to force 
the pig sector to invest more in waste treatment. 
 
8.  Project selection. The project team identified Tianzow as a suitable candidate for ADB 
support because (i) it is a leading domestic supplier of high-quality pig breeding stock; (ii) it has 
shown robust biosecurity practices with much less herd loss compared to the industry average; 
(iii) it has an inclusive business model, which incorporates smallholder farmers into its contract 
farming operations; and (iv) it is committed to improving its standards of safeguards, corporate 
governance, and animal welfare. 
 
2.  Project Design 
 
9.  The  project  comprises  the  construction  and  operation  of  a  modern  seven-floor  pig 
breeding stock farm in Chongqing municipality. Tianzow plans to finish the farm construction by 
December 2021.  
 
10.  Supply high-quality breeding stock to the market. Founded in 2004, Tianzow enjoys 
a first mover advantage in having developed a proprietary genetic pool and a mature operating 
model. Tianzow is one of the first PRC companies that has partnered with leading international 
pig genetic companies such as Fast Genetics (Canada) and Axiom (France) to develop a strong 
 
4  When pig prices are high, smallholder farmers expand pig farming aggressively to take advantage of the high prices, 
which increases supply and decreases prices. When observed prices drop, smallholder farmers quickly exit pig 
farming, which decreases supply and increases prices. Consistent with this pattern, pig prices increased to high 
levels in 2019 and 2020 due to reduced supply, but have since significantly decreased in 2021 due to rebuilt supply.  
5  P.J. Gerber et al. 2013. Tackling Climate Change Through Livestock: A Global Assessment of Emissions and 
Mitigation Opportunities. Rome: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. 
6  M. Cassandro. 2020. Animal breeding and climate change, mitigation and adaptation. Journal of Animal Breeding 
and Genetics. 137 (2). pp. 121–122. 
7  Current status, problems and development trends of swine industry of China. 2015. Guangdong Agricultural Science 
Journal. PRC academic document code: 1004-874X (2015) 16-0175-05. (in Chinese).

3 
genetic pool of the breeding stock and sector know-how. Tianzow also plans to source pig 
genetics from Denmark and the United States in 2022–2024 to further solidify the company’s 
leading position in the PRC. The average PSY in Tianzow pig farms is about 23–24 and can reach 
27 in some farms. Its core business is selling breeding stock such as grandparents and F1s 
(crossbred from purebred breeder pigs) to pig farming companies, which contributed to about 
46% of gross profit on average during 2017–2020. Commercial pigs contribute to about 44% of 
gross profit8 and the remaining 10% is from ancillary products and services. 
 
11.  Reducing animal waste-related pollution. The project supports animal waste treatment 
to reduce pollution. Tianzow composts pig manure, which is combined with coconut chaff and 
sawdust in a tank and mechanically aerated. The waste mix is effectively converted to a dry 
organic compost material that is distributed to local farmers as organic fertilizers. The process 
generates heat and effectively inactivate any residual pathogens and can kill the ASF virus in 
waste.9 As a result of the heat, excess moisture evaporates and there is no liquid effluent or waste 
generated. Pig urine will be treated by an anaerobic digestion pond system that will produce 
biogas and effluent up to applicable standards to be used at plantations. This biogas will replace 
liquefied petroleum gas as an energy source for water heating and cooking by employees at 
farms, thereby supporting climate change mitigation by reducing project GHG emissions. It is 
expected that 1,500 tons of carbon dioxide will be reduced every year because of this project. 
 
12.  Strong biosecurity management. Tianzow implements biosecurity management best 
practices on all its pig farms. Those practices include (i) implementing a five-layer protection 
system in terms of disinfection to ensure all materials and people are disinfected thoroughly 
before entering the production lines, (ii) minimizing interactions between different sections of the 
pig farms, (iii) using software to trace Tianzow’s trucks to transport pigs to pig farms and to 
slaughterhouses, and (iv) adopting a 4-week batch production system through which disease risk 
is mitigated with less contact during pig transportation. Human–livestock–wildlife interactions 
present a significant risk of zoonotic disease, which is mitigated by Tianzow’s indoor farm model. 
As the project will emphasize animal health and animal welfare and minimize the spread of 
antimicrobial resistance and zoonoses, it is aligned with a “One Health” approach. 
 
13.  Innovative and efficient multi-floor pig farms. The project’s seven-floor pig breeding 
stock farm follows Tianzow’s corporate farming model, which presents several advantages 
including (i) saving land and labor cost compared to traditional single floor pig farm, as facilities 
are aggregated in one building with advanced technologies, such as auto feeding systems, 
temperature and humidity controls, and ventilation systems; (ii) improving feed conversion ratio 
and average daily gains due to Tianzow’s strong breeding stock genetics; and (iii) reducing the 
risk of ASF because each pig is restricted to one floor to avoid mixing animals.   
 
14.  Gender equality in the pig farming business. As the PRC has gone through rapid 
urbanization since 2000, it has been increasingly difficult for the pig sector to attract and retain 
women workers because of the remote locations and relatively poor working environments of pig 
farms. To address the shortage of adequate skills and knowledge in pig farming, Tianzow has 
established cooperation agreements with contract farmers to help them build pig houses and

improve  their  skills  up  to  expected  standards  and  technical  requirements.10 Tianzow  has 
partnered with about 200 contract farmers, which have hired more than 1,200 workers (20% of 
which are female). These numbers reflect the limited number of female applicants when hiring pig 
farm employees because of the unique nature of the job. 
 
3.  Tianzow and the Borrower 
 
15.  Tianzow is one of the largest pig breeding stock multiplier companies in the PRC, although 
its market share is small, given the PRC’s highly fragmented pig breeding stock market. Tianzow 
operates 47 pig farms in 16 provinces across the PRC and employs 860 staff, of which 70% are 
in rural areas. The borrower, a wholly owned subsidiary of Tianzow, is in Chongqing municipality 
and its operational and financial management is controlled by Tianzow. Founder Yu Ping is the 
chairperson of the board and president of Tianzow. He is an engineer with extensive international 
business  experience.  Tan  Jin  and  Yu  Zhengbo  (the  son  of  Yu  Ping  and  Tan  Jin)  have 
management roles in Tianzow (Tan Jin as vice president and secretary of the board, and Yu 
Zhengbo as sales and marketing manager). Yu Ping, Tan Jin, and Yu Zhengbo are executive 
directors of the board and collectively own 68.03% of Tianzow. CP Group (Thailand) and Itochu 
(Japan) each own an 8.4% stake in Tianzow indirectly. 
 
16.  ADB conducted integrity due diligence in accordance with ADB’s Integrity Due Diligence 
Guidelines for Nonsovereign Operations.11 The borrower, its shareholders, and ultimate beneficial 
owners are not the subject of any unresolved or substantiated adverse media or other relevant 
information that may pose significant integrity risk. ADB has obtained reasonable assurance that 
the borrower was not established or is being used for money laundering or terrorism financing in 
the project jurisdiction, or that the transaction is being used for tax secrecy, tax evasion, or tax 
fraud, with the tax integrity risks being low and acceptable.12  
 
B.  Development Impacts, Outcomes, and Outputs 
 
17.  Impacts.  The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impacts:  rural  revitalization  and 
modernization of agriculture sector accelerated, and green and smart agriculture promoted.13 
 
18.  Outcomes. The project will have the following outcomes: sustainable pig breeding stock 
operations in the PRC scaled up, and livelihoods for farmers and workers provided. 
 
19.  Outputs. The project will have the following outputs: (i) a pig breeding stock and waste 
treatment facility with gender-sensitive design constructed and operated, (ii) gender equality in 
Tianzow’s workforce improved, and (iii) a safe environment for women and men workers created.

C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
20.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is aligned with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030, which calls for ADB to scale up its financing for agribusiness and to promote 
gender equality in at least 75% of the number of ADB’s committed operations by 2030.14 The 
project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2021–2025, which 
supports  (i)  strengthening  environmentally  sustainable  development  by  promoting  waste 
treatment; (ii) partnering with small and medium-sized enterprises, which are critical sources of 
productivity  enhancing  innovations  and  tend  to  be  more  dynamic  in  generating  jobs;  (iii) 
expanding nonsovereign operations with advanced technology and innovative business models 
that promote greater resilience and help improve resource efficiency and quality standards; (iv) 
strengthening gender equality; and (v) mobilizing new external sources of development finance.15 
 
21.  Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  ADB  sovereign  operations.  The  project 
contributes to the following operational priorities (OPs) of ADB’s Strategy 2030: OP 1 (addressing 
remaining poverty and reducing inequalities), which aims to improve standards of living for poor 
and  vulnerable  people;16 OP  2  (accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality),  which  calls  for 
increasing women’s economic empowerment and access to job skills;17 OP 3 (tackling climate 
change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability), 
which promotes environmental sustainability through waste management;18 and OP 5 (promoting 
rural development and food security), which addresses food security and increases agricultural 
productivity to provide sufficient, safe, and affordable food.19 The project will complement a PRC 
sovereign  project,  the  Yellow  River  Ecological  Corridor  and  Climate-Resilient  Agriculture 
Development Project, which aims to (i) support sustainable agriculture sector development, and 
(ii) promote food and agricultural products with environmental protection and climate adaptation 
and mitigation.20 Potential areas of collaboration include supporting solid waste treatment and 
Tianzow’s contract farmers within the Yellow River Ecological Corridor. 
 
22.  Lessons. In its 2018 sector-wide evaluation, ADB’s Independent Evaluation Department 
recommended  that  ADB  “increase  the  attention  paid  to  agricultural  activities,  policy  and 
institutional reforms, and the private sector.”21 The project supports a critical private sector-led 
intervention (the supply of high-quality pig breeding stock) of agricultural activities. ADB provided 
three direct loans to livestock companies in the PRC: a dairy company,22 a poultry company,23

G.  Unique Features 
 
24.  The project has a unique combination of development themes: inclusive business,25 
sustainable environmental management, animal welfare, and gender mainstreaming. 
 
  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance

25.  ADB will provide a long-term loan of up to $30,000,000 equivalent in yuan with a tenor of 
up to 5 years, comprising (i) an A loan of up to $15,000,000 equivalent in yuan and (ii) subject to 
syndication, a complementary loan of up to $15,000,000 equivalent in yuan funded by commercial 
banks, with ADB as lender of record, to the borrower to support the project. Tianzow, three 
individual shareholders (Yu Ping, Tan Jin, and Yu Zhengbo), and a key subsidiary of Tianzow will 
provide an unconditional and irrevocable guarantee to ADB for this project. 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
26.  ADB assistance will add value on the following fronts: 
(i)  Mobilization. Tianzow has only borrowed from domestic commercial banks. ADB’s 
loan will include a complementary loan, funded by international commercial banks. 
(ii) Safeguard and governance standards. ADB will support Tianzow and the borrower 
to  develop  an  improved  environmental  and  social  management  plan  following 
international good practice on waste management; and monitor their progress during 
project implementation. Further, an action plan has been designed to help Tianzow 
improve its animal welfare practices, and progress will be verified by an independent 
expert.26 Finally, another action plan has been designed to help Tianzow achieve 
better corporate governance practices.27 
(iii) Gender mainstreaming. Tianzow has agreed to implement a gender action plan 
(which ADB helped to design) that aims to improve gender inclusion and diversity in 
its workforce to address the gender gaps assessed during due diligence. 
 
C.  Risks 
 
[Redacted] 
 
27.  Impact  of  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19).  Tianzow’s  pig  farm  operations  were 
disrupted, and construction was delayed in 2020 because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Tianzow 
did not experience a material adverse impact on its performance in 2020 because of high pork 
prices. Tianzow provided protective equipment to all the workers in its pig farms and to contract 
farmers to maintain normal operations.

  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions

Statement (2009) as follows: environment (category B), involuntary resettlement (category B), 
and indigenous peoples (category C).28

adverse impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. The environmental and social measures and 
the institutional capacity and commitment of Tianzow and the borrower to manage the project’s 
social and environmental impacts are deemed adequate. Potential risks and impacts identified 
are generally site specific and can be effectively managed by good environmental management 
plans. The borrower has obtained land use rights for the project land, most of which are under 
lease  while  a  portion was  permanently  acquired  by  the  government.  Government-led  land 
acquisition did not lead to any physical or economic displacement. No indigenous peoples impacts 
are envisaged for the project. The proceeds of ADB’s investment will not support activities with 
significant environmental or social impacts. 
 
31.  An external third party conducted a corporate audit in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement. The corporate audit assessed Tianzow’s operations as complying with statutory 
requirements. It deemed Tianzow and the borrower’s current environmental and social systems, 
processes, and practices commensurate with the risks and impacts associated with their business 
and operations. Audit findings and recommendations to address gaps identified have been 
documented in a corrective action plan and agreed by ADB, Tianzow, and the borrower. 
 
32.  Tianzow  and  the  borrower  will  (i)  apply  ADB's  prohibited  investment  activities  list, 
(ii) ensure that the project complies with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and abide by national 
laws and regulations, and (iii) establish and maintain an appropriate environmental and social 
management system (ESMS) satisfactory to ADB before disbursement. The ESMS will set out 
requirements, as applicable, for compliance with national labor laws and measures to comply with 
the internationally recognized core labor standards, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy 
(2001).29 The ESMS will also contain requirements, as applicable, for information disclosure and 
consultation with affected people following ADB requirements. Tianzow and the borrower will 
report annually to ADB on (i) their compliance with such law, the ESMS, and ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement; and (ii) the measures taken at the corporate and project levels. 
 
33.  Effective  gender  mainstreaming.  The  project  is  classified  as  effective  gender 
mainstreaming. ADB conducted gender analysis, which concluded that Tianzow closely follows 
regulations on labor conditions and equal opportunity for all its employees, but that it lacks gender-
sensitive policies and practices. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (1998), 
Tianzow has incorporated measures to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment in 
its business activities. Key features of the gender action plan are as follows: (i) upgrade and build 
sanitation and changing facilities separate for female and male staff proportionally; (ii) increase 
women’s  representation  in  skilled  roles;  (iii)  revise  Tianzow’s  corporate  policies  to  include 
provisions on gender inclusion in human resource management; and (iv) elaborate on and 
disseminate a new anti-sexual harassment policy, supported by the appointment of a female 
manager in charge of the matter and training delivered across the company’s sites. Tianzow will 
submit periodic reports on implementation of gender measures to ADB. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
34.  Tianzow was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
29 ADB. 2003. Social Protection. Manila (adopted in 2001).

9 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
[Redacted] 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
35.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),30 
ADB will proceed with the assistance upon establishing that the Government of the PRC has no 
objection to the assistance to Tianzow. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form 
and substance satisfactory to ADB. 
 
  RECOMMENDATION 
 
36.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$30,000,000 equivalent in yuan, comprising (i) an A loan of up to $15,000,000 equivalent in yuan 
to be funded by ADB’s ordinary capital resources; and (ii) a complementary loan of up to 
$15,000,000 equivalent in yuan, to Chongqing Tianzow Animal Husbandry Technology Limited 
for the Tianzow Advanced Pig Breeding Stock Project in the People’s Republic of China, with 
such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, 
and as may be reported to the Board.

metadata.Subject:
The project comprises the construction and operation of a modern pig breeding stock farm in Chongqing municipality in the PRC. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) loan will be used for (i) the repayment of shareholder loans to the borrower by Sichuan Tianzow Breeding Technology Co., Ltd. (Tianzow) to fund the construction of the farm, (ii) biological assets for the farm, and (iii) working capital for the first year of farm operations.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated September 2021 is provided for the ADB project 52358-001 in the People’s Republic of China.
